00040 #ifndef _world_h

00042 
00043 /**
00044  @mainpage Physgame
00045  The Physgame Engine isn't really an engine. It is glue holding other code and libraries together. It is a series of other open source libraries (sometimes
00046  less user friendly, and almost always more sophistciated) that are held together in a single, hopefully, unchanging API. Others have attempted
00047  to do things like this before. Usually simple mistakes are made along the way that have huge negative impacts later in the design. A common mistake
00048  code is copy and pasted from open source projects with no plans for maintainability. This means that those projects get all the features and bugs
00049  from when they copied, without updates, new features and bugfixes since they started integrating the code. We too have copy and pasted, however we are
00050  keeping it up to date, and have a plan for upgrading each component we have brought in.
00051 
00052  This is not simple, guaranteeing the most up to date libraries with meaningful and working integration means a lot of work. Many linux distributions try
00053  to keep the most up to date shared libraries around, but what about when they don't ship what you need, or ship a broken copy or an older library. What about
00054  Windows and Mac OS X which make no attempt to keep these kinds of software up to date. What if you do manage to get and stay up to date, then you still have to
00055  work on a confusing compiler and linker options, Code::Blocks or Visual Studio aren't going to set that up for you. The Physgame Engine project depends on a dozen
00056  or more libaries, so would your project if it had high performance 3d graphics, easy to use 3d physics intgrated witht the graphics and 3d positional audio ready
00057  to run on Windows, Linux and Mac OS X. We are figuring it out once, getting it right ( if we aren't, tell us and we will fix it ), so it doesn't need to be done again
00058  and again for each game made.
00059 
00060  This is still in heavy development and is not in usable condition for all systems. Currently the synchronization of 3d graphics and physics works great. But,
00061  some of the more advanced features of both physics and graphics to do not yet work. There are a number of other features that are in varied states of development.
00062 
00063  If we do our jobs right this will save time and effort making, updating and porting games between a variety of platforms. If you link only
00064  against this library, not a single line of your standard compliant C++ code should need to change between platforms. At this early stage we are proving the
00065  concept with "Catch!" our first sample game. It Currently runs on Linux, Windows and Mac OS X with an Identical
00066  codebase. When we are done with "Catch!" We want it to have one codebase (with no messy #IFDEFs for compatibility), and downloadable in the Iphone
00067  app store, on the PS3, Wii download on Steam, and in a variety of linux repositories.
00068 
00069  To get the latest news on development checkout: http://gitorious.org/physgame
00070  Or check the webpage http://www.blacktoppstudios.com
00071 
00072  Here we will detail the engine structure and different classes and datatypes, but this needs an update.
00073 
00074  @section Engine Structure
00075   @subpage mainloop1 "Main Loop Flow"
00076 
00077   @ref phys::World "World - It integrates everything"
00078 
00079   @ref phys::EventManager "Events - Handling messages, event and interupts from the outisde"
00080 
00081   @subpage actorcontainer1 "Actor Container - Keeping track of our in game objects"
00082 
00083  @section Types Data Types
00084   @ref phys::Vector3
00085 
00086   @ref phys::Vector3WActor
00087 
00088   @ref phys::Ray
00089 
00090   @ref phys::Real
00091 
00092   @ref phys::Whole
00093 
00094   @ref phys::Quaternion
00095 
00096   @ref phys::MetaCode
00097 
00098  @section Classes Sophisticated Data Types
00099   @ref phys::ActorBase "Actors - Items in the world"
00100 
00101   @ref phys::EventBase
00102 
00103   @ref phys::GraphicsManager
00104 
00105  @section Optional Optional Engine Components
00106   @ref phys::WorldQueryTool
00107 */
00108

00165     ///////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////
00166     /// @class World
00167     /// @headerfile world.h
00168     /// @brief This is the main entry point for the entire library.
00169     /// @details The physworld coordinates and integrates all the underlying subsystems,
00170     /// Currently Ogre3d is used for 3d Graphics, Bullet is used for physics, and
00171     /// SDL is used for user input and window management. Games will need a
00172     /// container for all the playing pieces. It makes sense to tie all of this
00173     /// functionality into one world object.
00174     ///////////////////////////////////////
00175     class PHYS_LIB World
00176     {
00177         private:
00178             //friend class PhysicsManager;
00179 
00180             //SDL Object
00181             bool HasSDLBeenInitialized;
00182 
00183             //Try to retrieve ogre settinss
00184             void LoadOgreSettings();
00185 
00186             //Used by the constructors
00187             /// @internal
00188             /// @brief This is called by all the constructors so that the is one unified place to have all the settings made.
00189             /// @param GeographyLowerBounds This is the lower boundary of the phyiscs estimation.
00190             /// @param GeographyUpperbounds This is the upper boundary of the phyiscs estimation.
00191             /// @param MaxPhysicsProxies This is an estimation of the limit of bodies in the physics world.
00192             /// @param SceneType This is the type of Scene Manager to be created.
00193             /// @param LogFileName This is the place that log messages get sent to.
00194             /// @param ManagerToBeAdded This is a vector of manager pointers that will be used instead of creating the default ones
00195             void Construct( const Vector3 &GeographyLowerBounds,
00196                             const Vector3 &GeographyUpperbounds,
00197                             const unsigned short int &MaxPhysicsProxies,
00198                             SceneManager::SceneManagerType SceneType,
00199                             std::string LogFileName,
00200                             std::vector < ManagerBase* > ManagerToBeAdded);
00201 
00202             void SanityChecks();
00203 
00204             //Settings for Engine Functionality
00205             string WindowName;
00206             Whole TargetFrameLength;
00207             Whole FrameTime;
00208 
00209             /// @internal
00210             /// @brief This is a listing of the priority and the Manager, and a pointer to the manager.
00211             std::list< ManagerBase* > ManagerList;
00212 
00213         protected:
00214             /// @internal
00215             /// @brief A pointer to the one and only world
00216             static World* TheRealWorld;
00217 
00218         public:
00219         ///////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////
00220         // Creation and Deletion methods
00221         ///////////////////////////////////////
00222 
00223             /// @brief Return a pointer to the world
00224             /// @return This returns a pointer the one and only phys::World
00225             static World* GetWorldPointer();
00226 
00227             /// @brief Descriptive constructor With Manager Pointers
00228             /// @details This constructor allows for an easier way to define the boundaries for items moving about inside the physworld.
00229             /// @param GeographyLowerBounds_ The lower limits for the size of the physics simulation
00230             /// @param GeographyUpperbounds_ The Upper limits for the size of the physics simulation
00231             /// @param MaxPhysicsProxies_ This is the amount of Actors (Also called Proxies) allowed in a physics simulation.
00232             /// @param SceneType A cue to the scenemanager as to how rendering should occur.
00233             /// @param LogFileName This is the place that log messages get sent to.
00234             /// @warning Do not make a new world if one already exists. This can only cause problems
00235             World(  const Vector3 &GeographyLowerBounds_,
00236                     const Vector3 &GeographyUpperbounds_,
00237                     SceneManager::SceneManagerType SceneType,
00238                     const unsigned short int &MaxPhysicsProxies_=1024,
00239                     std::string LogFileName="Physgame.log" );
00240 
00241             /// @brief Descriptive constructor
00242             /// @details This constructor allows for an easier way to define the boundaries for items moving about inside the physworld.
00243             /// This constructor provides no default arguments, but allows for maximum customization. In addition to everything the other
00244             /// constructors this one can accept a vector of pointers to managers. They will be add
00245             /// @param GeographyLowerBounds_ The lower limits for the size of the physics simulation
00246             /// @param GeographyUpperbounds_ The Upper limits for the size of the physics simulation
00247             /// @param MaxPhysicsProxies_ This is the amount of Actors (Also called Proxies) allowed in a physics simulation.
00248             /// @param LogFileName This is the place that log messages get sent to.
00249             /// @param SceneType A cue to the scenemanager as to how rendering should occur.
00250             /// @param ManagerToBeAdded This is a vector of manager pointers that will be used instead of creating new ones
00251             /// @warning Do not make a new world if one already exists. This can only cause problems.
00252             World(  const Vector3 &GeographyLowerBounds_,
00253                     const Vector3 &GeographyUpperbounds_,
00254                     const unsigned short int &MaxPhysicsProxies_,
00255                     SceneManager::SceneManagerType SceneType,
00256                     const std::string &LogFileName,
00257                     const std::vector <ManagerBase*> &ManagerToBeAdded);

00259             /// @brief Default constructor
00260             /// @details This simply performs the same work as the descriptive constructor with some sane, but small, limits. It will give you a world which expands for 100 units from the Origin, and only allows 10 Actors
00261             /// @warning Do not make a new world if one already exists. This can only cause problems
00262             World();
00263 
00264             /// @brief Deconstructor
00265             /// @details This Tears down all the items created by the physworld, and safely frees any graphical resources, we will also delete any Objects passed into the
00266             /// Physworld by pointer. We will not delete any pointers we pass out (like from the Events from the Event manager)
00267             ~World();

00269         ///////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////
00270         // Logging
00271         ///////////////////////////////////////
00272             /// @brief Runtime event and message logging.
00273             /// @param Message This is what will be streamed to the log
00274             /// @details This also commits any outstanding log messages that are waiting in the World::LogStream, and any outstanding
00275             /// Log messages from any subsystem. Currently the Graphics subsystem (Ogre3d) and the sound subsystem (cAudio) are the
00276             /// Only ones to produce meaningul log messages.
00277             template <class T> void Log(T Message)
00278                 { this->LogString(ToString(Message)); }
00279 
00280             /// @brief Force any outstanding logs to be commited to logs
00281             void Log();
00282 
00283             /// @brief This is another way to put data in the log.
00284             /// @details The contents of this will be commited to the log once per frame, just before rendering, or whenever World::Log is called.
00285             /// Because the entry of this data into the actual log file(or whatever destination) is delayed, do not use this for data that is likely
00286             /// to be required to debug something the frame something crashes. However, for other kinds of debugging data and creating in game logs
00287             /// and gameworld recreations.
00288             std::stringstream LogStream;
00289 
00290             /// @brief This is the preferred way to throw an exception. It streams any thrown object to the log.
00291             /// @details This will log the Message, and will throw an exception with the Message included. Currently this supports all the Data
00292             /// types that overload the stream insertion operator ( << )
00293             /// @param Message This will be streamed to the log, then used in a thrown exception.
00294             template <class T> void LogAndThrow(T Message)
00295             {
00296                 this->Log(Message);
00297                 throw(Message);
00298             }
00299 
00300             /// @brief Log String directly with no conversion
00301             /// @param message The string to log
00302             void LogString(const String& message);

00317         ///////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////
00318         // Timing system methods
00319         ///////////////////////////////////////
00320             /// @brief Retrieves the amount of milliseconds we would like each iteration of the Main Loop to be
00321             /// @details In practice harI've done some more testing, started out digging through the code to see if there was anything wrong, there seemed to be random extra words inside our code that the compiler didn't mind that shouldn't be there.  like there was a " Schedule : " right after a line where a pointer was initialized.  I only found such occurrences in gamebase.cpp though, removed them and did two tests.  First test I was just randomly clicking and then I inadvertently threw the metal sphere down into the abyss, the sphere was really close to the camera when this happened, about to go over.  Second time I ran the game trying to click stuff, I simply couldn't click anything.  I even tried zooming in on the robots, although I can only get so close to them before I have to tamper with the camera, which I haven't done yet, but there were no results with the Robots.  The third time I was successfully able to stop two spheres and move them around the platform quite smoothly.  These spheres were slightly further away from the camera compared to the first run.  I stopped the wooden sphere and the second metal sphere.  I included a screen shot and a copy of my log for the third run.  The spheres in the screenshot are both in a rest position.dware performance or timing concerns can cause this goal to be unnaitanable or trivially easy. The main loop with actually
00322             /// pause execution until this amount of time is reach is main loop iteration, However, the mainloop will always skip waiting if hardware is overburdened.
00323             /// @return This returns a Whole with the current Value
00324             Whole GetTargetFrameTime();
00325 
00326             /// @brief This sets a new Target Time
00327             /// @details This sets a new time for each frame. Each iteration of the game loop will take around this long to run, but rarely exactly this long. Setting this value
00328             /// Higher can results in power savings (battery life), but setting it too High can cause choppiness. Settings this value higher can result in smoother gameplay, but
00329             /// set it too high, and system resources could becom completely taxed and power will be wasted.
00330             /// @param NewTargetTime The new length of time, in milliseconds.
00331             /// @warning Setting vary low or very High values could cause unknown errors, This is on our todo list of issues to fix.
00332             void SetTargetFrameTime(const Whole &NewTargetTime);
00333 
00334             /// @brief This sets a new Target Frame Rate
00335             /// @details This sets a new time for each frame. This divides 1000 by the NewFrameRate, drops and floating point amount and uses that amount in an call to
00336             /// World::SetTargetFrameTime. For example a target frame rate of 40 with cause each frame to take 25 milliseconds, and a Framerate of 70 would take 14 ms
00337             /// @param NewFrameRate The new desired frame rate.
00338             /// @warning Setting vary low or very High values could cause unknown errors, This is on our todo list of issues to fix.
00339             void SetTargetFrameRate(const Whole &NewFrameRate);
00340 
00341             /// @brief Gets the amount of time since the last time Rendering began.
00342             /// @details This returns, in milliseconds the amount of time since the frame started (since the last rendering began)
00343             /// @return This returns a whole number which can be used to aid in the timimg of various algorithms.
00344             Whole GetFrameTime();
00345 
00346             /// @internal
00347             /// @brief Sets the amount of time since the last time Rendering began.
00348             /// @param FrameTime_ This is the amount of time in  milliseconds.
00349             /// @details This sets, in milliseconds the amount of time since the frame started (since the last rendering began). Don't set this carelessely can screw up a lot of
00350             /// stuff, for the most part this should be by the rendering manager during the rendering process.
00351             void SetFrameTime( const Whole &FrameTime_ );

00356             /// @brief This creates the game window and starts the game.
00357             /// @param CallMainLoop should the main loop be called
00358             /// @details Prior to this all of the physics and graphical object containers should have been loaded and prepared for use. There should be
00359             /// minimal delay from the time you call this and the game actually begins.
00360             /// This will automatically call the Main Loop unless passed false.
00361             void GameInit(const bool &CallMainLoop=true );

00364             /// @details By default this is called from the function World.GameInit() this is were the bulk of the simulation is ran from, see @ref mainloop1

00372         // Upper Management

00374             /// @brief This adds a manager, in the correct order, to the list that the world calls on
00375             /// @details Internally the world had a list of managers that is sorted by the ManagerBase::Priority. Everytime a manager is added,
00376             /// the list is searched for the sorted point to insert the manager at.
00377             /// @param ManagerToAdd The pointer to the manager to be added
00378             void AddManager(ManagerBase* ManagerToAdd);
00379 
00380             /// @brief This removes a manager by finding the matching pointer.
00381             /// @details Currently this just iterates through the list looking for the matching pointer, at some future point
00382             /// this could replaced with more sophisticated algorithm, but for now assume this operates in linear time.
00383             /// @param ManagerToRemove A pointer to the manager to be removed
00384             void RemoveManager(ManagerBase* ManagerToRemove);
00385 
00386             /// @brief This removes a manager of a specific type from the list
00387             /// @details This starts at the beginning (should be the lowest priority)of the list and iterates through looking for a matching type, at some future point
00388             /// this could replaced with more sophisticated algorithm, but for now assume this operates in linear time.
00389             /// @param ManagersToRemoveType The ManagerBase::ManagerTypeName of the manager to remove.
00390             /// @param WhichOne If not removing the first/only manager of the given type, which one by count are you erasing.
00391             void RemoveManager(const ManagerBase::ManagerTypeName &ManagersToRemoveType, short unsigned int WhichOne);
00392 
00393             /// @brief This is will find the manager of a given type
00394             /// @details Specifically this will iterate from lowest priority to highest priority, and return a pointer to the first Manager
00395             /// with a matching type found. If you specify WhichOne, it will the Nth+1 in the list matching the type (kind of like array subscript).
00396             /// @param ManagersToRemoveType
00397             /// @param WhichOne If not getting the first/only manager of the given type, get one.
00398             /// @return This returns a pointer to a ManagerBase, or a NULL pointer if no matching manager exists
00399             ManagerBase* GetManager(const ManagerBase::ManagerTypeName &ManagersToRemoveType, short unsigned int WhichOne=0);
00400 
00401             /// @brief Changes a Manager's time of execution.
00402             /// @details Searches through the Manager list and removes any previous entries to the changing manager, and add a new entry in the correct location.
00403             /// @param ManagerToChange A pointer to the manager that needs to be changed
00404             /// @param Priority_ the new desire priority/execution order of the Manager
00405             void UpdateManagerOrder(ManagerBase* ManagerToChange, short int Priority_);
00406 
00407             /// @brief This forces the list of managers to be resorted.
00408             /// @details This should only need to be called if the Priority attribute of a manager in the list has changed. This sorts the list of managers
00409             void UpdateManagerOrder();
00410 
00411             /// @brief This gets the ActorManager from the manager list.
